unnormalised: EdTech startup 'ShikshaVerse' faced a bit of a hiccup last week. Apparently, their flagship course, "Coding for Kids 101", saw a drop in enrollment by 15% compared to Q3 '23. The buzz around coding bootcamps seems to have cooled off a little, maybe all the AI news is making parents think robots will do it all, lol!
normalised: E-d-T-e-c-h startup 'ShikshaVerse' faced a bit of a hiccup last week. Apparently, their flagship course, "Coding for Kids one hundred and one", saw a drop in enrollment by fifteen percent compared to Q three two thousand and twenty three. The buzz around coding bootcamps seems to have cooled off a little, maybe all the A-I news is making parents think robots will do it all, l-o-l!

unnormalised: The company's spokesperson, Ms. Anjali Sharma, stated in a press release on 20/06/2024 that this dip is "temporary and attributed to seasonal factors". She also emphasized that ShikshaVerse plans to launch 3 new courses in the next quarter focusing on topics like game development and AI ethics for young learners. Plus, they are partnering with DPS Bangalore for a pilot program which should help them reach more students.
normalised: The company's spokesperson, M-s. Anjali Sharma, stated in a press release on twentieth june two thousand and twenty four that this dip is "temporary and attributed to seasonal factors". She also emphasized that ShikshaVerse plans to launch three new courses in the next quarter focusing on topics like game development and A-I ethics for young learners. Plus, they are partnering with D-P-S Bangalore for a pilot program which should help them reach more students.

unnormalised: However, market analysts suggest that the competition from larger players like BYJU's and Unacademy is heating up. These bigger companies are offering courses at competitive prices and have huge marketing budgets, making it tough for smaller startups to compete. It looks like ShikshaVerse might need to up their game to stay relevant in the long run.
normalised: However, market analysts suggest that the competition from larger players like B-Y-J-U's and Unacademy is heating up. These bigger companies are offering courses at competitive prices and have huge marketing budgets, making it tough for smaller startups to compete. It looks like ShikshaVerse might need to up their game to stay relevant in the long run.

unnormalised: The company’s stock price (SHIKVERS:NSE) fell by ₹25 on Friday, closing at ₹175. Investors seem a little jittery for now but Ms. Sharma reassured them they have a plan to "re-strategize and come back stronger" after the summer break. We'll be keeping a close eye on how things unfold at ShikshaVerse.
normalised: The company’s stock price (S-H-I-K-V-E-R-S colon N-S-E) fell by rupee twenty five on Friday, closing at rupee one hundred and seventy five. Investors seem a little jittery for now but M-s. Sharma reassured them they have a plan to "re-strategize and come back stronger" after the summer break. We'll be keeping a close eye on how things unfold at ShikshaVerse.
